DST.content: perhaps désister marks nothing negative, perhaps dé- does not determine -ister (-ester, ist, est: exist, subsist, consist), but dislodges it radically (this aradical root -ister) [cf. LI p. 159n]
DST.linkedContent: perhaps désister marks nothing negative, perhaps dé- does not determine -ister (-ester, ist, est: exist, subsist, consist), but dislodges it radically (this aradical root -ister) [cf. LI p. 159n]

DST.content: désistance (2 typical experiences) is ineluctable: 1) il faut que cela arrive: in this case, the “I,” the free subject, anticipates/precedes, is constituted w/out or before, the ineluctable event that happens to me 2) constitutive desistance of subject: something began before me, I am late, a subject marked in advance by a pre-impression, imprint—deconstitution (“I” am not the supporting basis of this imprint): still, ineluctable not genetic programs or historical determination—those would be supplemental, late determinations of ineluctable
DST.linkedContent: désistance (2 typical experiences) is ineluctable: 1) il faut que cela arrive: in this case, the “I,” the free subject, anticipates/precedes, is constituted w/out or before, the ineluctable event that happens to me 2) constitutive desistance of subject: something began before me, I am late, a subject marked in advance by a pre-impression, imprint—deconstitution (“I” am not the supporting basis of this imprint): still, ineluctable not genetic programs or historical determination—those would be supplemental, late determinations of ineluctable

DST.content: is it a law? Derrida’s choosing or compulsion to introduce a translation of an untranslatable [re: désistement]
DST.linkedContent: is it a law? Derrida’s choosing or compulsion to introduce a translation of an untranslatable [re: désistement]

DST.content: se désister (to renounce a [law]suit, a responsibility)
DST.linkedContent: se désister (to renounce a [law]suit, a responsibility)

DST.content: Lacoue-Labarthe: subject in mirror is first of all subject in désistance, figure is never one, destabilizing division of figural (this muddles Lacan’s distinction btwn symbolic/imaginary)

DST.content: désistance—impossibility of consisting, [de]-constitution of subject

DST.content: désistance—la juste démesure (precise inordinancy), strange measure (une étrange mesure)
DST.linkedContent: désistance—la juste démesure (precise inordinancy), strange measure (une étrange mesure)

DST.content: Lacoue-Labarthe: désistance as a desertion [Derrida quotes a passage w/out usage of désistance] that is prior to any ‘self-possession’ (not mode of dispossession), (de)constitution of subject, can one think of loss re: what one never had?
DST.linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: désistance as a desertion [Derrida quotes a passage w/out usage of désistance] that is prior to any ‘self-possession’ (not mode of dispossession), (de)constitution of subject, can one think of loss re: what one never had?

DST.content: subject—nothing other than formation of movement of désistance
DST.linkedContent: subject—nothing other than formation of movement of désistance

DST.content: w/ both Lacoue-Labarthe & Heidegger, Derrida wonders about unity of unthought—couldn’t the unthought be désistance, & doesn’t désistance enforce an irreducible dispersion that disidentifies even a concept of a subject that exceeds the metaphysical one?
DST.linkedContent: w/ both Lacoue-Labarthe & Heidegger, Derrida wonders about unity of unthought—couldn’t the unthought be désistance, & doesn’t désistance enforce an irreducible dispersion that disidentifies even a concept of a subject that exceeds the metaphysical one?

DST.content: Derrida wonders if Heidegger’s insistence on Ort, Erörterung, a unique site of gathering, leaves un-thought désistance or dislocation, which might be thought itself [this torments Derrida’s respect for Heidegger, along w/ Derrida’s insufficient concern re: authentic thought]
DST.linkedContent: Derrida wonders if Heidegger’s insistence on Ort, Erörterung, a unique site of gathering, leaves un-thought désistance or dislocation, which might be thought itself [this torments Derrida’s respect for Heidegger, along w/ Derrida’s insufficient concern re: authentic thought]

DST.content: fold or abyssal redoubling: désistance is first of all the désistance of truth: truth never resembles itself, so it resembles mimesis
DST.linkedContent: fold or abyssal redoubling: désistance is first of all the désistance of truth: truth never resembles itself, so it resembles mimesis

DST.content: truth never resembles itself, withdraws, masks itself, se désister (never ceases) ——ester: “to appear, present oneself in court” [p. 319n Kahn’s translation of Heidegger] > désistance, a rupture, heterogeneity w/ respect to Wesen, estance, not Abwesen (absence), Unwesen (disorder), Entwesen (inessentiality): dé, not negative, marks nonbelonging to family of ester
DST.linkedContent: truth never resembles itself, withdraws, masks itself, se désister (never ceases) ——ester: “to appear, present oneself in court” [p. 319n Kahn’s translation of Heidegger] > désistance, a rupture, heterogeneity w/ respect to Wesen, estance, not Abwesen (absence), Unwesen (disorder), Entwesen (inessentiality): dé, not negative, marks nonbelonging to family of ester

DST.content: désistance brings to light anoia, not to be confused w/ madness though it can resemble it > double bind btwn 2 madnesses: 1) one of disintalling 2) one of reason, defensive stiffening (crispation) in assistance [Kafka], imitation, identification > madness against madness
DST.linkedContent: désistance brings to light anoia, not to be confused w/ madness though it can resemble it > double bind btwn 2 madnesses: 1) one of disintalling 2) one of reason, defensive stiffening (crispation) in assistance [Kafka], imitation, identification > madness against madness

DST.content: désistance: mimesis or its double, cela même qu’elle double et abîme (what it doubles & engulfs)— alētheia
DST.linkedContent: désistance: mimesis or its double, cela même qu’elle double et abîme (what it doubles & engulfs)— alētheia

DST.content: mimesis as désistance (w/out being it) is missed when one decides to identify it, one misses what it lacks and that this lack is not proper; Lacoue-Labarthe: mimesis ek-sists, better yet “de-sists,” infinity of substitution & circulation (must think of Nietzsche again)
DST.linkedContent: mimesis as désistance (w/out being it) is missed when one decides to identify it, one misses what it lacks and that this lack is not proper; Lacoue-Labarthe: mimesis ek-sists, better yet “de-sists,” infinity of substitution & circulation (must think of Nietzsche again)

DST.content: désistance: one of the most demanding thoughts of responsibility > that the traditional categories don’t suffice places irresponsibility rather on the side of these categories: how can one assume responsibility in désistance, the responsibility of désistance itself?
DST.linkedContent: désistance: one of the most demanding thoughts of responsibility > that the traditional categories don’t suffice places irresponsibility rather on the side of these categories: how can one assume responsibility in désistance, the responsibility of désistance itself?

DST.content: we are constituted by this rhythm, (de-)constituted by marks of this “caesuraed” stamp, rhythmotypy as divided idiom in us of désistance > no subject w/out signature of this rhythm
DST.linkedContent: we are constituted by this rhythm, (de-)constituted by marks of this “caesuraed” stamp, rhythmotypy as divided idiom in us of désistance > no subject w/out signature of this rhythm

DST.content: rhythm: to think désistance as it is written
DST.linkedContent: rhythm: to think désistance as it is written

DST.content: Lacoue-Labarthe: [subject] ‘desists’ because must confront at least 2 figures (or one figure that is at least double) > destabilizing Lacan’s imaginary/symbolic

DST.content: the “loss (perte) of the subject” in Lacan calls for a suturing that obliterates désistance
DST.linkedContent: the “loss (perte) of the subject” in Lacan calls for a suturing that obliterates désistance

DST.content: resistance to désistance is desire for assistance, paternal assistance, Oedipal help ——unavoidable resistance to désistance as nonpathological inhibition, no rhythm w/out it, can say the same about the double bind (see p. 228 return to father, subject to law as inhibition, defense) [a safeguarding, a filiation, a subjectivity compelled by the caesura?]

DST.content: play of de- might belong to hyperbologic, belongs to and escapes its own series: “gift of mimesis,” “gift of impropriety,” not negative (dialecticizable)
